bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the President of Waverly Press, June 6, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests permission to borrow Dominguez's manuscript in English. The manuscript deals with Carlos Finlay and his yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the President of Waverly Press, June 6, 1941
div1.opener:
June 6, 1941
President
The Waverly Press
Mt. Royal and Guilford Avenues
Baltimore, Maryland
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
For four years I have been making a special study of the conquest
of yellow fever, especially the work of Dr. Finlay in Cuba and of Walter
Reed and his associates on the United States Army Yellow Fever Board. In
connection with this I have made two trips to Havana and have visited many
governmental and other officers as well as many of the survivors of the
yellow fever experiments in this country. The Cuban physicians felt that
American writers have not done justice to Dr. Finlay. It is therefore the
desire of many of the Cuban physicians that I be acquainted as much as
possible with the work of Dr. Finlay. To this end. Dr. Dominguez kindly
gave me a copy of the French edition of his book on Dr. Carlos Finlay.
Inasmuch as my French is not good enough for critical appraisal he has
kindly consented to my being allowed to read the English translation of
his book. On the occasion of my recent visit, he gave me the enclosed
letter for presentation to you. I held it up, hoping that I might visit
Baltimore and present it to you in person. I did visit Baltimore about
three weeks ago but my time was completely taken up at the home of Dr. Howard
Kelly who rushed me to the train, and I was unable to see you.

I would appreciate it greatly if you would let me borrow Dr.
Dominguez's manuscript in English. What are your present plans concerning
the publication of this manuscript?
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
